tt_insn_vec.help: Portion of vector registers that is actually used. Available only for instructions belonging to a SIMD/vector instructions set (like x86 AVX)

tt_Recip_throughput.help: Average number of cycles to retire that instruction if repeated (assuming independent instructions, with no read-after-write dependency)

hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
 - fftz2: 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_call_1>>
hint.title: CALL instructions

hint.details:
These instructions generate more than one micro-operation and only one of them can be decoded during a cycle and the extra micro-operations increase pressure on execution units.
 - PUSH: 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_complex_1>>
hint.title: Complex instructions

hint.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
hint.details:
- Constant non-unit stride: 1 occurrence(s)
Non-unit stride (uncontiguous) accesses are not efficiently using data caches
hint.title: Slow data structures access
hint.txt: Detected data structures (typically arrays) that cannot be efficiently read/written

hint.title: Type of elements and instruction set
hint.txt: No instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on FP elements. This loop is probably writing/copying data or processing integer elements.

hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop does not contain any FP arithmetical operations.
The binary loop is loading 64 bytes.
The binary loop is storing 20 bytes.

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor and if some data references are common to consecutive iterations. This can be done manually.
hint.title: Unroll opportunity

expert.help: Compare the CQA-computed load/store/compute metrics with the capacity of the core. For instance if CQA computes 24 bytes in the loop in 2 cycles (that is 12 cycles per cycle) and if the core can process up to 16 bytes per cycle, that metric is 75%.
expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 7.17 cycles. At this rate:
 - 9% of peak load performance is reached (8.93 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 4% of peak store performance is reached (2.79 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 7.17 to 5.00 cycles (1.43x speedup).

header:
Warnings:
Detected a function call instruction: ignoring called function instructions.
Rerun with --follow-calls=append to include them to analysis  or with --follow-calls=inline to simulate inlining.
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 48.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
Fortran storage order is column-major: do i do j a(i,j) = b(i,j) (slow, non stride 1) => do i do j a(j,i) = b(i,j) (fast, stride 1)<<image_col_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
do i a(i)%x = b(i)%x (slow, non stride 1) => do i a%x(i) = b%x(i) (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
Only 10% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 7.17 to 0.69 cycles (10.42x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.
